column3: Nice, I like the simplicity of the semantics. Will test.\n

Ideally you'd only take blocks requested before this one into account for computing the allowed remaining time, but that's much harder to implement.

I did very light testing (parting mainnet sync), and it seems to work well so far.

@sipa  I thought you raised a good point about ignoring blocks requested after a given one, so I've pushed up a commit that does so (for block requests going to the same peer).\n\nI am not entirely sure the additional 5 lines of code (and one extra piece of state for each peer) is worth the code complexity, so if you prefer the first version I can drop this commit, but it seemed unfortunate that i
Travis failed, and this doesn't look like a random failure.\n
Hmm, it seems you're not using nValidatedQueuedBefore at all anymore. Is that intentional?\n

Thanks for catching that; it was intentional to not use it anymore but it was an oversight not to remove the unnecessary variable from QueuedBlock.  Since the original timeout calculation was based only on information known at the time of a block request, I opted to store the disconnect time directly.

I've updated the pull to remove that variable.
Now that #5662 has been merged, which can increase the number of blocks in flight, I think this would be a useful behavior change.  Anything else I can do here?\n
Code review and lightly tested (synced a partly-synced main chain using it) ACK.\n
